-b-formula.title: -b formula
-b-formula.content:
What is -b formula
What is -b formula
â†“

A formula to roots of a Quadratic
x = \frac{b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}


Deriving -b formula
â†“
\begin{align}
ax^2+bx+c &= 0 \\
x^2+\frac{b}{a}x+\frac{c}{a} &= 0 \\
x^2+\frac{b}{a}x &= -\frac{c}{a} \\
x^2+\frac{b}{a}x &= \left( \frac{b}{2a} \right)^2-\frac{c}{a} \\
x^2+\frac{b}{a}x &= \frac{b^2}{4a^2}-\frac{c}{a} \\
\left( x+\frac{b}{2a} \right)^2 &= -\frac{c}{a} + \frac{b^2}{4a^2} \\
\left( x+\frac{b}{2a} \right)^2 &= \frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2} \\
x+\frac{b}{2a} &= \pm \frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} \\
x &= \frac{b}{2a} \pm \frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} \\
x &= \frac{b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}
\end{align}

â†“

Complex Arithmetic
How do we add Complex Numbers
â†“

Add real and imaginary parts separately

\begin{align}
a+bi + c+di &=(a+bi) + (c+di) \\
&=(a+c) + (bi+di)
\end{align}

How do we multiply Complex Numbers
â†“

Use distributive property to multiply

\begin{align}
(a+bi)(c+di) &= a(c+di) + bi(c+di) \\
&= ac+adi + bci+bdi^{2} \\
&= ac+adi+bci-bd \\
&= (ac-bd)+(ad+bc)i
\end{align}

What is the pattern in powers of i
â†“

Powers of i repeat in blocks of 4

\begin{align}
i^{1} &= i \\
i^{2} &= -1 \\
i^{3} &= -i \\
i^{4} &= 1 \\
&\text{pattern repeats} \dots
\end{align}

How to evaluate i^{n}
â†“
\begin{align}
i^{x} \\
x \div 4 &= x \text{ remainder }n \\
n &= 1 \text{ then } i = i \\
n &= 2 \text{ then } i = -1 \\
n &= 3 \text{ then } i = -i \\
n &= 4 \text{ then } i = 1
\end{align}

How do we divide Complex Numbers
â†“

We can use the fact that z\bar{z} is real for all complex numbers

\begin{align}
\frac{\omega}{z}=\frac{w}{z} \cdot \frac{\bar{z}}{\bar{z}} = \frac{w\bar{z}}{z\bar{z}}
\end{align}

3.3

(x+r) = 0 &\text{, } (ax+m) = 0
\end{align}

Feynman-Learning-Technique.title: Feynman Learning Technique
Feynman-Learning-Technique.content:
What is the Feynman Learning Technique
The Technique

Pretend to teach a concept to a kid

Create a note for the subject you want to master
Try explaining using basic terms a kid could understand
Write down or record everything though


Identify gaps in your explanation

Any jargon
Any gaps between concepts
Identify boundaries of Circle of competence


Go back and fill in those gaps

Look up definitions
Look at concept as a whole and not its parts
Think about how these all relate to each other


Organise and simplify

Now read revised note from beginning to end
If at any point there is confusion go back to step 2
Then collect the final note together


Transmit

The ultimate test of your knowledge is your capacity to convey it to another

Adding Fraction
Adding to get mixed fractions (\frac{2}{4}+\frac{3}{4})
â†“

Adding unlike quantities (\frac{a}{b}+\frac{c}{d})
â†“

Subtracting Fraction

â†“
4-2 \frac{3}{4}=(4-2-1)+\left( 1- \frac{3}{4} \right)=1 \frac{1}{4}

Multiplying Fraction
Multiplying and simplifying by Cross Cancellation (\frac{15}{35} \cdot \frac{14}{20})
â†“

Reduce each fraction to its simplest form by cancelling any common divisors between the numerators and denominators
\frac{15}{35} \cdot \frac{14}{20} = \frac{3}{7} \cdot \frac{7}{10} = \frac{3}{10}


Multiplying and simplifying by Cancelling Products \left( \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4 }\right)
â†“
\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{3}{4} = \frac{\cancel{2}^1}{\cancel{3}^1} \times \frac{\cancel{3}^{1}}{\cancel{4}^{2}}=\frac{1}{1} \times \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{2}

Multiplying mixed numbers
â†“
3 \times 2 \frac{3}{4} = \frac{3}{1} \times \frac{2 \times 4+3}{4} = \frac{33}{4} = 8 \frac{1}{4}

Identities
a \cdot \frac{1}{b}=\dots
â†“
a \cdot \frac{1}{b}=\frac{a}{b}

\frac{1}{a} \cdot \frac{1}{b} = \dots
â†“
\frac{1}{a} \cdot \frac{1}{b} = \frac{1}{ab}

a \cdot \frac{c}{d} = \dots = \dots
â†“
a \cdot \frac{c}{d}=\frac{ac}{d}=\frac{a}{d} \cdot c

\frac{a}{b} \cdot \frac{c}{d}=\dots
â†“
\frac{a}{b} \cdot \frac{c}{d}=\frac{ac}{bd}

Dividing Fraction
Identities
\frac{1}{\frac{a}{b}}=\dots=\dots
â†“
\frac{1}{\frac{a}{b}}=\frac{1}{a \text{/} b}=\frac{b}{a}

\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d}=\dots=\dots
â†“
\frac{a}{b} \div \frac{c}{d} = \frac{a}{b} \cdot \frac{d}{c} = \frac{ad}{bc}

Raising fraction to a Power
Identities
\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^n=\dots
?
\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^n=\frac{a^n}{b^n}
\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^{-1}=\dots
â†“
\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^{-1}=\frac{b}{a}

\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^={-n}=\dots
â†“
\left( \frac{a}{b} \right)^{-n}=\frac{b^n}{a^n}

Simplifying Fractions
Simplifying by Reducing (Prime Factorisation) \left( \frac{18}{24} \right)
â†“

Perform the Prime Factorisation of both the numerator and the denominator
Then, cancel out any common prime factors.
\frac{18}{24} = \frac{2 \cdot 3^2}{2^3 \cdot 3} = \frac{2}{3}

Cartridge based w/ Swappable ROM

1978

First International Game

First game with enemy that shoot at you
First game with lives over timers
First game with high score
First game with continuous dynamic music

Music had higher tempo as enemies got faster




Enemies getting faster wasnâ€™t intentional

lcm(24, 90) = 2^3 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1 = 360
\end{align}

Relationship Between the Least Common Multiple (LCM) and Common Multiples
â†“

Let a and b be positive integers
Every multiple of lcm(a, b) is a common multiple of a and b is a multiple of lcm(a, b)

Po-Shen-Loh-Method.title: Po-Shen Loh Method
Po-Shen-Loh-Method.content:
What is The Po-Shen Loh Method
What do we know about the roots of a quadratic
â†“

x^2-(r+s)x+rs by Vietaâ€™s Formula
We can get midpoint by getting Arithmetic Mean of roots
We can get the distance squared as difference of two squares
We can represent roots as a distance \pm the midpoint
Transclude of Po-Shen-Loh-Method-2024-12-17-16.17.42.excalidraw

How do we get the midpoint
â†“
\begin{align}
b'&=(-r+s) \\
m&=\frac{r+s}{2}=-\frac{b'}{2} \\
\end{align}
How do we get the distance
â†“
\begin{align}
c'&=rs \\
c'&=(m-d)(m+d) \\
&= m^{2}-d^{2} \\
d^{2}&=m^{2}-c'
\end{align}
How do we get the roots
â†“
r,s=m\pm d

â†“

Prime Factorisation in Multiples of an Integer
â†“

Let n be a positive integer. If you take any multiple of n,
Its prime factors will always include the prime factors of n. \begin{aligned} 1 \cdot 18 &= 1 \cdot \left(2^1 \cdot 3^2\right) = 2^1 \cdot 3^2, \\ 2 \cdot 18 &= 2 \cdot \left(2^1 \cdot 3^2\right) = 2^2 \cdot 3^2, \\ 3 \cdot 18 &= 3 \cdot \left(2^1 \cdot 3^2\right) = 2^1 \cdot 3^3, \\ 4 \cdot 18 &= 2^2 \cdot \left(2^1 \cdot 3^2\right) = 2^3 \cdot 3^2, \\ 5 \cdot 18 &= 5 \cdot \left(2^1 \cdot 3^2\right) = 2^1 \cdot 3^2 \cdot 5^1.\end{aligned}

The component or one of itâ€™s ancestors has been updated

â€œRenderingâ€ is React calling your components


3. React commits changes to the DOM
â†“

After rendering (calling) your components, React will modify the DOM.

For the initial render,Â React will use theÂ appendChild()Â DOM API to put all the DOM nodes it has created on screen.
For re-renders,Â React will apply the minimal necessary operations (calculated while rendering!) to make the DOM match the latest rendering output.
